newsitem.title: JAPAN: S'tomo sees world 1997 aluminium demand up 1.7 pct.
newsitem.headline: S'tomo sees world 1997 aluminium demand up 1.7 pct.

text.p: Sumitomo Corp expects world aluminium demand to rise 1.7 percent in 1997 to 17.81 million tonnes, with growth in the United States and Europe offsetting a slump in Japan, a company source said on Tuesday.
The trade house predicted that supplies would be flat, as a drop in Russian exports was expected to offset restarts of idled capacity and the start-up of new capacity.
Sumitomo projected a supply surplus of about 188,000 tonnes, down from 431,000 tonnes in 1996.
The trade house forecast that demand in Japan would fall to 2,342,000 tonnes, off two percent from last year's record high.

It blamed the slump on a downtrend in aluminium can consumption since the latter half of last year, an expected fall-off in demand from the car and construction sectors after this April's planned sales tax increase, and a rise in mill product inventories through the end of last year.
Japan's decline would be more than offset, however, by 2.0 percent growth in both the United States and Europe, it said.
Sumitomo forecast that supplies would rise a marginal 0.3 percent to 17,998,000 tonnes, with production capacity in the West up 350,000 tonnes, or two percent, at 17,250,000 tonnes.
It predicted that production in the West would rise 2.3 percent to 15,998,000 tonnes and that imports from the former Communist bloc would slip 13.3 percent to two million tonnes.
The Sumitomo forecasts, reported on Tuesday morning in a Japanese trade paper, were contained in a report distributed to Sumitomo clients, a company source said.
